questions.text: A 70-year-old male with a known history of coronary artery disease (CAD) undergoes his annual health check-up. Laboratory investigations indicate elevated levels of LDH-5. The consulting cardiologist reviews these results to determine the potential source of cell injury. LDH, or lactate dehydrogenase, has several isoenzymes with different tissue distributions. Based on the elevation of LDH-5, which tissue is most likely experiencing injury in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Liver

 

Option B.

 

  • Lactate Dehydrogenase (LDH) is a tetrameric enzyme consisting of two monomer types: H (for heart) and M (for muscle) that combine to give five LDH isozymes.
  • HHHH (I1), HHHM (I2), HHMM (I3), HMMM (I4), and MMMM (I5).
  • Tissue-specific expression of the H and M genes determines the proportions of each subunit in different tissues.
  • Isozyme LDH-I is seen in heart tissue, and isozyme LDH-5 is in the liver.
  • Thus, any tissue injury causes releases of characteristic pattern of LDH isozymes.

 

Explanation

 

Option A. Heart: Isozyme LDH 1 is seen in Heart.

 

Option C. Brain: Isozyme LDH 3 is seen in Brain.

 

Option D. RBC: Isozyme LDH 2 is seen in RBCs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

LDH-5 is an isoenzyme of lactate dehydrogenase that is most abundant in the liver and skeletal muscle. Elevated levels of LDH-5 are often associated with liver damage or disease, reflecting hepatocellular injury. While LDH is a fairly non-specific marker and can be elevated in various conditions, the specific elevation of LDH-5 is more suggestive of liver involvement rather than heart, brain, or red blood cells.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e p 66.

questions.text: In a groundbreaking study on enzyme diversity, scientists have discovered several enzymes within the same metabolic pathway that, despite differing structurally, perform identical functions across various tissues. This finding prompts a discussion on the classification of these enzymes. Which term accurately describes enzymes with different structures but the same catalytic function?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Isoenzymes

 

Option B.

 

Isoenzymes, or isozymes, are enzyme variants that have different amino acid sequences and may be expressed in different tissues but catalyze the same biochemical reaction. They allow for the fine-tuning of metabolic processes to meet the specific needs of different cells and tissues.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Allosteric enzymes: These are enzymes whose activity can be modulated by the binding of an effector molecule at a site other than the active site (allosteric site). The term "allosteric" does not imply that the enzymes have identical functions but different structures.

 

Option C. Coenzymes: Coenzymes are small, non-protein organic molecules that bind to enzymes and are required for their catalytic activity. They are not enzymes themselves and therefore cannot be classified as having the same catalytic function or different structures.

 

Option D. Apoenzymes: An apoenzyme is the protein component of an enzyme, excluding any cofactors or prosthetic groups. It becomes an active enzyme (holoenzyme) upon binding with its cofactor. This term does not describe enzymes with different structures but identical functions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ISOENZYMES:

 

  • Different molecular forms of the same enzyme synthesized in various tissues are called isoenzymes.
  • If the subunits are all the same, the protein is a homomultimer represented by a single gene.
  • If the subunits are different, the protein is a heteromultimer, produced by different genes.
  • They may be products of different genes (more than one locus) known as true isoenzymes.
  • The genes may be located on different chromosomes, e.g. salivary and pancreatic amylase.
  • In certain cases, all the different forms are present in the same individual, e.g. lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) has 5 isoenzymes and all are seen in all persons in the population.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 66, 67.

questions.text: In cardiac diagnostics, clinicians often refer to the LDH isoenzyme ratio as an indicator of myocardial infarction (MI). In a typical healthy adult, the LDH-2 level is higher than LDH-1. A condition where this ratio is reversed, with LDH-1 being higher than LDH-2, is sometimes described in clinical practice. Is the term "flipped pattern" correctly applied to the scenario where LDH-2 is higher than LDH-1?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. False     

 

Explanation

 

Healthy individual has LDH-2 higher than LDH-1. After certain types of myocardial injury, such as an MI, cardiac cells release more LDH-1 than LDH-2, which can lead to LDH-1 becoming higher than LDH-2. This reversal is what's referred to as a "flipped pattern," so the statement LDH-2 >>> LDH-1 being known as a flipped pattern is false.

 

Educational Objective:

 

This question tests understanding of LDH isoenzyme patterns in normal and pathological states. The five LDH isoenzymes (LDH-1 through LDH-5) consist of different combinations of H (heart) and M (muscle) subunits. LDH-1 (H₄) predominates in heart tissue, LDH-5 (M₄) predominates in liver and skeletal muscle, and the others are hybrid forms. The normal serum pattern (LDH-2 > LDH-1) gets reversed in myocardial infarction, creating the "flipped pattern" (LDH-1 > LDH-2). While historically important, LDH isoenzyme analysis has been largely replaced by more specific cardiac markers such as troponin in modern clinical practice.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 69.

choices.text: Exist in 5 forms depending on M and H monomer contents

questions.text: A clinical laboratory technician is analyzing serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels in a series of patients with various tissue injuries. The technician notes the presence of multiple forms of LDH in the samples, reflecting tissue-specific expression patterns. Based on the properties of LDH isoenzymes, which statement accurately describes these forms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Exist in 5 forms depending on M and H monomer contents

 

Option C.

 

  • Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) enzyme is a tetramer with 4 subunits and the subunit may be either H (heart) or M (muscle) polypeptide chains.
  • So, 5 combinations of H and M chains which are possible: H4, H3M1, H2M2, H1M3 and M4 varieties
  • The iso-enzymes are separated by cellulose acetate electrophoresis at pH 8.6, as they have different electrophoretic mobility.
  • The bands are identified by adding the reactants (NAD+, phenazine methosulphate) finally producing a color reaction (with nitroblue tetrazolium) which may be quantitated by a scanner.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Have similar electrophoretic mobility: This is incorrect as the electrophoretic mobility of LDH isoenzymes varies, allowing them to be separated and identified through electrophoresis.

 

Option B. Differ in catalytic activity: While there may be subtle variations in the kinetic properties of LDH isoenzymes, they generally catalyze the same reaction, converting lactate to pyruvate and vice versa, with variations more so in their tissue distribution than in their catalytic activity.

 

Option D. Occur as monomers: This is incorrect because LDH isoenzymes function as tetramers, not monomers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase) isoenzymes exist in five distinct forms, which are tetramers composed of combinations of M (muscle) and H (heart) subunits. These combinations result in isoenzymes with different tissue distributions and can provide valuable information about the location of tissue damage based on their varying levels in the blood.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 304.

questions.text: A medical intern is reviewing laboratory results for a series of patients and notes variations in lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) isoenzyme levels. LDH5, in particular, has caught their attention due to its elevated levels in one of the patient's tests. Given the tissue distribution and specificity of LDH5, in which of the following conditions is an elevation of LDH5 most commonly observed?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Liver disease

 

Option C.

 

  • Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) enzyme is a tetramer with 4 subunits and the subunit may be either H (heart) or M (muscle) polypeptide chains.
  • So, 5 combinations of H and M chains which are possible: H4, H3M1, H2M2, H1M3 and M4 varieties.
  • But LDH-5 predominates in Liver.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Myocardial infarction: This condition typically shows an elevation in LDH1 and LDH2 isoenzymes, which are more abundant in cardiac tissue.

 

Option B. Peptic ulcer: While LDH levels can be affected by various conditions, LDH5 is not specifically associated with peptic ulcers.

 

Option D. Infectious diseases: Although LDH levels may increase in infectious diseases, LDH5 elevation is more specifically indicative of liver involvement rather than a general response to infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 304.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with a recent diagnosis of lung carcinoma undergoes routine blood work as part of his oncological assessment. His physician notes an elevated level of a specific isoenzyme, which is known to be associated with certain cancers and shares characteristics with the placental form of alkaline phosphatase. This isoenzyme is particularly noted for its heat stability. What is this isoenzyme commonly referred to in clinical practice?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Regan Isoenzyme

 

Option A.

 

The Regan isoenzyme is a variant of alkaline phosphatase (ALP) that is heat-stable and has been associated with various types of carcinomas, including lung carcinoma. It is similar to the placental form of ALP but can be ectopically produced by tumors, making it a potentially useful marker in oncology.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Liver Isoenzyme: While liver isoenzymes of ALP can be elevated in liver diseases and some cancers, they are not specifically known for being heat-stable or for their association with placental ALP.

 

Option C. Bone Isoenzyme: The bone isoenzyme of ALP is typically elevated in conditions affecting bone turnover and growth but is not specifically associated with cancers in the same way as the Regan isoenzyme.

 

Option D. Intestinal Isoenzyme: Intestinal isoenzymes of ALP may be elevated in gastrointestinal diseases but do not have the same clinical significance in the context of carcinoma as the Regan isoenzyme.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Regan isoenzyme (named after the patient in whom it was detected) is identified in plasma in patients with carcinoma of lung, liver & intestine. It is a variant of alpha-2 heat stable form of ALP.
  • Nago isoenzyme: variant of ALP of germ cell origin, it is a modified form of non-placental isoenzyme seen in certain tumors.
  • Kasahara isoenzyme: variant of ALP of fetal intestinal origin, seen in malignancy.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 306.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is NOT a common technique for identifying isoenzymes?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Spectrometry

 

Option D.

 

Spectrometry, particularly mass spectrometry, is an analytical technique that measures the mass-to-charge ratio of ions to identify molecules. It is typically used to determine the composition of a sample or to identify a compound. While spectrometry can be used to analyze the structure of proteins, it is not a standard method for differentiating isoenzymes because it does not readily distinguish between different enzyme forms that may have similar masses but differ in their charge, structure, or kinetic properties.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Electrophoresis is a technique that separates molecules based on their size and charge and is commonly used to differentiate isoenzymes.

 

Option B. Specific antibodies can be used to distinguish isoenzymes because they can recognize and bind to specific epitopes that may differ between isoenzyme forms.

 

Option C. Tissue localization involves identifying the specific tissues in which isoenzymes are expressed, as certain isoenzymes are confined to particular organs or cell types.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Methods of identification of Isoenzymes:

 

  • In electrophoresis, the isoenzymes have different mobility. LDH and CK isoenzymes are separated by electrophoresis.
  • Heat stability: One of the isoenzymes can be easily denatured by heat, e.g. bone isoenzyme of ALP (BALP).
  • Inhibitors: One of the isoenzymes can be sensitive to one inhibitor, e.g. tartrate labile ACP.
  • The Km value or substrate specificity may be different for isoenzymes, e.g. glucokinase has high Km and hexokinase has low Km for glucose.
  • Cofactor requirements can be different for isoenzymes. Mitochondrial isocitrate dehydrogenase is NAD+ dependent and the cytoplasmic isoenzyme is NADP+ dependent.
  • Tissue localization can be different for isoenzymes. The H4 form of LDH is present in the heart and the M4 variety is seen in skeletal muscle.
  • Specific antibodies can identify different types of isoenzymes. For example, CK isoenzymes are separated by antibodies

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 67.

choices.text: Variation at multiple locus forms polymorphism

questions.text: Which of the following best describe Isoenzyme?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Catalyze the same reaction                     

 

Option A.

 

They are physically distinct forms of the same enzyme activity. 

Multiple molecular forms of an enzyme are described as iso-enzymes or isozymes.

They may be products of different genes (more than one locus).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Same quaternary structure: Isoenzymes can have different quaternary structures. They are not necessarily identical in their subunit composition or assembly, which can contribute to their tissue-specific expression and activity.

 

Option C. From a same gene origin: Isoenzymes are often encoded by different genes, which can be part of a gene family. 

 

Option D. Variation at multiple locus forms polymorphism: While genetic polymorphism can result in different isoenzymes, the statement is more general and does not capture the specific nature of isoenzymes. Polymorphism refers to the presence of multiple alleles at a gene locus within a population, which can lead to various protein forms, including isoenzymes, but the term is not specific to isoenzymes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isoenzymes are variants of an enzyme that exist in different forms in an organism, and they catalyze the same type of chemical reaction within different tissues or under different conditions. They can differ in amino acid sequence, kinetic properties, and regulatory mechanisms but perform the same overall reaction, reflecting their adaptation to specific cellular or tissue requirements.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 68-69.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old chronic smoker for the past 20 years presents with chest tightness and pain on the left upper limb for the past 14 hours. He is known hypertensive on regular antihypertensive medications and not a diabetic. ECG shows significant ST segment elevation in I, II and V1 to V6 leads.

 

 

Laboratory investigations:

 

Troponin T = 144 ng/ml (normal = <5 ng/ml)

 

 

Troponin I = 250 ng/ml (normal = <0.04 ng/ml)

CPK-Total = 2100 IU/L (normal = 40-300 IU/L)

CPK-MB = 350 IU/L (normal = 5-25 IU/L)

LDH = 343 IU/L (normal = 140-280 IU/L)

AST = 745 IU/L (normal = 15-45 IU/L)

Angiography revealed 96% block in the proximal portion of left anterior descending (LAD) artery. Which troponin is better for detection of MI?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Troponin I

 

Option B.

 

  • The patient is suffering from MI.
  • Measurement of cardiac troponins is one of the main tests in early detection of an ischemic episode and in monitoring the patients.
  • The troponin complex consists of 3 components such as troponin C (calcium binding subunit), troponin I (actomyosin ATPase inhibitory subunit) and troponin T (tropomyosin binding subunit).
  • Troponin I is released into the circulation within 4 hours after the onset of symptoms of MI → peaks at 14–24 hours and remains elevated for 3–5 days postinfarction.
  • Hence Troponin I is very useful as a marker at any time interval after the heart attack.
  • It is not elevated in muscle injury unlike CK2

 

Explanation

 

Option A. Serum Troponin T (TnT) increases within 6 hrs of MI → peaks at 72 hours → remains elevated up to 10–14 days.

 

Option C. Elevated cTn levels seen in acute coronary syndrome (ACS), stroke, pulmonary embolism, sepsis, acute perimyocarditis, acute heart failure and tachycardia. High sensitive TnT (hsTnT) has been developed, which detects even very low cTn concentrations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Both Troponin T and Troponin I are cardiac-specific isoforms that are highly sensitive and specific for myocardial injury and are used as primary biomarkers for the diagnosis of MI. However, Troponin I is often preferred due to its higher specificity to cardiac tissue. There are several isoforms of Troponin I that are specific to cardiac muscle, and assays for Troponin I are designed to detect these specific forms, minimizing cross-reactivity with skeletal muscle.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 303.
